sentence: A Farmer was driving his wagon along a miry country road after a heavy rain.

sentence: As the Ass walked along, the people bowed their heads reverently or fell on their knees, and the Ass thought the honor was being paid to himself.
title: The Ass Carrying the Image
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: With his head full of this foolish idea, he became so puffed up with pride and vanity that he halted and started to bray loudly.
title: The Ass Carrying the Image
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: But in the midst of his song, his driver guessed what the Ass had got into his head, and began to beat him unmercifully with a stick.
title: The Ass Carrying the Image
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "Go along with you, you stupid Ass," he cried.
title: The Ass Carrying the Image
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "The honor is not meant for you but for the image you are carrying."
title: The Ass Carrying the Image
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Mother Goat was going to market one morning to get provisions for her household, which consisted of but one little Kid and herself.
title: The Wolf, the Kid, and the Goat
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "Take good care of the house, my son," she said to the Kid, as she carefully latched the door.
title: The Wolf, the Kid, and the Goat
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "Do not let anyone in, unless he gives you this password: 'Down with the Wolf and all his race!'"
title: The Wolf, the Kid, and the Goat
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Strangely enough, a Wolf was lurking near and heard what the Goat had said.
title: The Wolf, the Kid, and the Goat
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: So, as soon as Mother Goat was out of sight, up he trotted to the door and knocked.
title: The Wolf, the Kid, and the Goat
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "Down with the Wolf and all his race," said the Wolf softly.
title: The Wolf, the Kid, and the Goat
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: It was the right password, but when the Kid peeped through a crack in the door and saw the shadowy figure outside, he did not feel at all easy.
title: The Wolf, the Kid, and the Goat
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "Show me a white paw," he said, "or I won't let you in."
title: The Wolf, the Kid, and the Goat
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: A white paw, of course, is a feature few Wolves can show, and so Master Wolf had to go away as hungry as he had come.
title: The Wolf, the Kid, and the Goat
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "You can never be too sure," said the Kid, when he saw the Wolf making off to the woods.
title: The Wolf, the Kid, and the Goat
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: A long time ago, the Lion, the Fox, the Jackal, and the Wolf agreed to go hunting together, sharing with each other whatever they found.
title: The Lion's Share
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: One day the Wolf ran down a Stag and immediately called his comrades to divide the spoil.
title: The Lion's Share
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Without being asked, the Lion placed himself at the head of the feast to do the carving, and, with a great show of fairness, began to count the guests.
title: The Lion's Share
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "One," he said, counting on his claws, "that is myself the Lion.
title: The Lion's Share
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Two, that's the Wolf, three, is the Jackal, and the Fox makes four."
title: The Lion's Share
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: He then very carefully divided the Stag into four equal parts.
title: The Lion's Share
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "I am King Lion," he said, when he had finished, "so of course I get the first part.
title: The Lion's Share
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: This next part falls to me because I am the strongest; and this is mine because I am the bravest."
title: The Lion's Share
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: He now began to glare at the others very savagely.
title: The Lion's Share
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "If any of you have any claim to the part that is left," he growled, stretching his claws meaningly, "now is the time to speak up."
title: The Lion's Share
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: A Wolf, lurking near the Shepherd's hut, saw the Shepherd and his family feasting on a roasted lamb.

sentence: "Aha!"
title: The Wolf and the Shepherd (2)
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: he muttered.
title: The Wolf and the Shepherd (2)
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "What a great shouting and running about there would have been, had they caught me at just the very thing they are doing with so much enjoyment!"
title: The Wolf and the Shepherd (2)
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: A Traveler had hired an Ass to carry him to a distant part of the country.
title: The Ass and its Shadow
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The owner of the Ass went with the Traveler, walking beside him to drive the Ass and point out the way.

source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The road led across a treeless plain where the Sun beat down fiercely.
title: The Ass and its Shadow
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: So intense did the heat become, that the Traveler at last decided to stop for a rest, and as there was no other shade to be found, the Traveler sat down in the shadow of the Ass.
title: The Ass and its Shadow
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Now the heat had affected the Driver as much as it had the Traveler, and even more, for he had been walking.
title: The Ass and its Shadow
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Wishing also to rest in the shade cast by the Ass, he began to quarrel with the Traveler, saying he had hired the Ass and not the shadow it cast.
title: The Ass and its Shadow
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The two soon came to blows, and while they were fighting, the Ass took to its heels.
title: The Ass and its Shadow
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: A long time ago a Man met a Satyr in the forest and succeeded in making friends with him.

source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The two soon became the best of comrades, living together in the Man's hut.

source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: But one cold winter evening, as they were walking homeward, the Satyr saw the Man blow on his fingers.
title: The Man and the Satyr
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "Why do you do that?"
title: The Man and the Satyr
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: asked the Satyr.
title: The Man and the Satyr
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "To warm my hands," the Man replied.
title: The Man and the Satyr
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: When they reached home the Man prepared two bowls of porridge.
title: The Man and the Satyr
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: These he placed steaming hot on the table, and the comrades sat down very cheerfully to enjoy the meal.
title: The Man and the Satyr
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: But much to the Satyr's surprise, the Man began to blow into his bowl of porridge.
title: The Man and the Satyr
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "Why do you do that?"
title: The Man and the Satyr
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: he asked.
title: The Man and the Satyr
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "To cool my porridge," replied the Man.
title: The Man and the Satyr
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The Satyr sprang hurriedly to his feet and made for the door.
title: The Man and the Satyr
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "Goodby," he said, "I've seen enough.

source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: A fellow that blows hot and cold in the same breath cannot be friends with me!"
title: The Man and the Satyr
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: One bright evening as the sun was sinking on a glorious world a wise old Cock flew into a tree to roost.

source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Before he composed himself to rest, he flapped his wings three times and crowed loudly.

source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: But just as he was about to put his head under his wing, his beady eyes caught a flash of red and a glimpse of a long pointed nose, and there just below him stood Master Fox.
title: The Cock and the Fox
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "Have you heard the wonderful news?"
title: The Cock and the Fox
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: cried the Fox in a very joyful and excited manner.
title: The Cock and the Fox
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "What news?"
title: The Cock and the Fox
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: asked the Cock very calmly.
title: The Cock and the Fox
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: But he had a queer, fluttery feeling inside him, for, you know, he was very much afraid of the Fox.

source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "Your family and mine and all other animals have agreed to forget their differences and live in peace and friendship from now on forever.

source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Just think of it!
title: The Cock and the Fox
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: I simply cannot wait to embrace you!
title: The Cock and the Fox
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Do come down, dear friend, and let us celebrate the joyful event."
title: The Cock and the Fox
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "How grand!"
title: The Cock and the Fox
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: said the Cock.
title: The Cock and the Fox
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "I certainly am delighted at the news."
title: The Cock and the Fox
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: But he spoke in an absent way, and stretching up on tiptoes, seemed to be looking at something afar off.
title: The Cock and the Fox
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "What is it you see?"
title: The Cock and the Fox
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: asked the Fox a little anxiously.
title: The Cock and the Fox
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "Why, it looks to me like a couple of Dogs coming this way.
title: The Cock and the Fox
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: They must have heard the good news and—"
title: The Cock and the Fox
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: But the Fox did not wait to hear more.
title: The Cock and the Fox
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Off he started on a run.
title: The Cock and the Fox
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "Wait," cried the Cock.

source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "Why do you run?
title: The Cock and the Fox
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The Dogs are friends of yours now!"
title: The Cock and the Fox
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "Yes," answered the Fox.
title: The Cock and the Fox
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "But they might not have heard the news.
title: The Cock and the Fox
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Besides, I have a very important errand that I had almost forgotten about."
title: The Cock and the Fox
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The Cock smiled as he buried his head in his feathers and went to sleep, for he had succeeded in outwitting a very crafty enemy.

sentence: There was once a Dog who was very fond of eggs.

source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: He visited the hen house very often and at last got so greedy that he would swallow the eggs whole.
title: The Dog and the Oyster
source: The Aesop for Children

source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: There he spied an Oyster.

source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: In a twinkling the Oyster was resting in the Dog's stomach, shell and all.

source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: It pained the Dog a good deal, as you can guess.

source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "I've learned that all round things are not eggs," he said groaning.

sentence: Two men were traveling in company along the road when one of them picked up a well-filled purse.

source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "How lucky I am!"
title: The Travelers and the Purse
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: he said.
title: The Travelers and the Purse
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "I have found a purse.
title: The Travelers and the Purse
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Judging by its weight it must be full of gold."
title: The Travelers and the Purse
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "Do not say 'I have found a purse,'" said his companion.
title: The Travelers and the Purse
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "Say rather 'we have found a purse' and 'how lucky we are.'
title: The Travelers and the Purse
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Travelers ought to share alike the fortunes or misfortunes of the road."

source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "No, no," replied the other angrily.

sentence: "I found it and I am going to keep it."

source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Just then they heard a shout of "Stop, thief!"

source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: and looking around, saw a mob of people armed with clubs coming down the road.

sentence: "We are lost if they find the purse on us," he cried.

sentence: Say 'I am lost.'"

sentence: A Wolf prowling near a village one evening met a Dog.

source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: It happened to be a very lean and bony Dog, and Master Wolf would have turned up his nose at such meager fare had he not been more hungry than usual.

source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: So he began to edge toward the Dog, while the Dog backed away.
title: The Wolf and the Lean Dog
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "Let me remind your lordship," said the Dog, his words interrupted now and then as he dodged a snap of the Wolf's teeth, "how unpleasant it would be to eat me[Pg 49] now.

source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Look at my ribs.
title: The Wolf and the Lean Dog
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: I am nothing but skin and bone.
title: The Wolf and the Lean Dog
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: But let me tell you something in private.

source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: In a few days my master will give a wedding feast for his only daughter.
title: The Wolf and the Lean Dog
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: You can guess how fine and fat I will grow on the scraps from the table.

source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Then is the time to eat me."
title: The Wolf and the Lean Dog
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The Wolf could not help thinking how nice it would be to have a fine fat Dog to eat instead of the scrawny object before him.

sentence: Some days later the Wolf came back for the promised feast.

source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: He found the Dog in his master's yard, and asked him to come out and be eaten.

sentence: "Sir," said the Dog, with a grin, "I shall be delighted to have you eat me.

sentence: I'll be out as soon as the porter opens the door."

source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: But the "porter" was a huge Dog whom the Wolf knew by painful experience to be very unkind toward wolves.

source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: So he decided not to wait and made off as fast as his legs could carry him.

sentence: A Giant Oak stood near a brook in which grew some slender Reeds.
title: The Oak and the Reeds
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: When the wind blew, the great Oak stood proudly upright with its hundred arms uplifted to the sky.
title: The Oak and the Reeds
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: But the Reeds bowed low in the wind and sang a sad and mournful song.
title: The Oak and the Reeds
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "You have reason to complain," said the Oak.
title: The Oak and the Reeds
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "The slightest breeze that ruffles the surface of the water makes you bow your heads, while I, the mighty Oak, stand upright and firm before the howling tempest."
title: The Oak and the Reeds
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "Do not worry about us," replied the Reeds.
title: The Oak and the Reeds
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "The winds do not harm us.
title: The Oak and the Reeds
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: We bow before them and so we do not break.
title: The Oak and the Reeds
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: You, in all your pride and strength, have so far resisted their blows.
title: The Oak and the Reeds
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: But the end is coming."
title: The Oak and the Reeds
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: As the Reeds spoke a great hurricane rushed out of the north.

source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The Oak stood proudly and fought against the storm, while the yielding Reeds bowed low.
title: The Oak and the Reeds
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The wind redoubled in fury, and all at once the great tree fell, torn up by the roots, and lay among the pitying Reeds.
title: The Oak and the Reeds
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Two Men were traveling in company through a forest, when, all at once, a huge Bear crashed out of the brush near them.

sentence: said the Fox.

sentence: The Mice once called a meeting to decide on a plan to free themselves of their enemy, the Cat.

sentence: Many plans were discussed, but none of them was thought good enough.

sentence: The Weasels and the Mice were always up in arms against each other.

title: The Mice and the Weasels
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: One day, a long time ago, an old Miller and his Son were on their way to market with an Ass which they hoped to sell.
title: The Miller, His Son, and the Ass
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: They drove him very slowly, for they thought they would have a better chance to sell him if they kept him in good condition.
title: The Miller, His Son, and the Ass
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: As they walked along the highway some travelers laughed loudly at them.
title: The Miller, His Son, and the Ass
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "What foolishness," cried one, "to walk when they might as well ride.
title: The Miller, His Son, and the Ass
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The most stupid of the three is not the one you would expect it to be."
title: The Miller, His Son, and the Ass
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The Miller did not like to be laughed at, so he told his son to climb up and ride.
title: The Miller, His Son, and the Ass
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: They had gone a little farther along the road, when three merchants passed by.
title: The Miller, His Son, and the Ass
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "Oho, what have we here?"
title: The Miller, His Son, and the Ass
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: they cried.
title: The Miller, His Son, and the Ass
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "Respect old age, young man!
title: The Miller, His Son, and the Ass
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Get down, and let the old man ride."
title: The Miller, His Son, and the Ass
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Though the Miller was not tired, he made the boy get down and climbed up himself to ride, just to please the Merchants.
title: The Miller, His Son, and the Ass
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: At the next turnstile they overtook some women carrying market baskets loaded with vegetables and other things to sell.
title: The Miller, His Son, and the Ass
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "Look at the old fool," exclaimed one of them.
title: The Miller, His Son, and the Ass
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "Perched on the Ass, while that poor boy has to walk."
title: The Miller, His Son, and the Ass
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The Miller felt a bit vexed, but to be agreeable he told the Boy to climb up behind him.
title: The Miller, His Son, and the Ass
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: They had no sooner started out again than a loud shout went up from another company of people on the road.
title: The Miller, His Son, and the Ass
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "What a crime," cried one, "to load up a poor dumb beast like that!
title: The Miller, His Son, and the Ass
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: They look more able to carry the poor creature, than he to carry them."
title: The Miller, His Son, and the Ass
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "They must be on their way to sell the poor thing's hide," said another.
title: The Miller, His Son, and the Ass
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The Miller and his Son quickly scrambled down, and a short time later, the market place was thrown into an uproar as the two came along carrying the Donkey slung from a pole.
title: The Miller, His Son, and the Ass
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: A great crowd of people ran out to get a closer look at the strange sight.
title: The Miller, His Son, and the Ass
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The Ass did not dislike being carried, but so many people came up to point at him and laugh and shout, that he began to kick and bray, and then, just as they were crossing a bridge, the ropes that held him gave way, and down he tumbled into the river.
title: The Miller, His Son, and the Ass
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The poor Miller now set out sadly for home.
title: The Miller, His Son, and the Ass
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: By trying to please everybody, he had pleased nobody, and lost his Ass besides.
title: The Miller, His Son, and the Ass
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: One day as an Ass was walking in the pasture, he found some Grasshoppers chirping merrily in a grassy corner of the field.
title: The Ass and the Grasshoppers
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: He listened with a great deal of admiration to the song of the Grasshoppers.
title: The Ass and the Grasshoppers
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: It was such a joyful song that his pleasure-loving heart was filled with a wish to sing as they did.
title: The Ass and the Grasshoppers
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "What is it?"
title: The Ass and the Grasshoppers
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: he asked very respectfully, "that has given you such beautiful voices?
title: The Ass and the Grasshoppers
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Is there any special food you eat, or is it some divine nectar that makes you sing so wonderfully?"
title: The Ass and the Grasshoppers
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "Yes," said the Grasshoppers, who were very fond of a joke; "it is the dew we drink!
title: The Ass and the Grasshoppers
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Try some and see."
title: The Ass and the Grasshoppers
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: So thereafter the Ass would eat nothing and drink nothing but dew.
title: The Ass and the Grasshoppers
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Naturally, the poor foolish Ass soon died.
title: The Ass and the Grasshoppers
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: A Lion had been watching three Bullocks feeding in an open field.
title: Three bullocks and a Lion
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: He had tried to attack them several times, but they had kept together, and helped each other to drive him off.
title: Three bullocks and a Lion
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The Lion had little hope of eating them, for he was no match for three strong Bullocks with their sharp horns and hoofs.
title: Three bullocks and a Lion
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: But he could not keep away from that field, for it is hard to resist watching a good meal, even when there is little chance of getting it.
title: Three bullocks and a Lion
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Then one day the Bullocks had a quarrel, and when the hungry Lion came to look at them and lick his chops as he was accustomed to do, he found them in separate corners of the field, as far away from one another as they could get.
title: Three bullocks and a Lion
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: It was now an easy matter for the Lion to attack them one at a time, and this he proceeded to do with the greatest satisfaction and relish.
title: Three bullocks and a Lion
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: At a great meeting of the Animals, who had gathered to elect a new ruler, the Monkey was asked to dance.
title: The Fox and the Monkey
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: This he did so well, with a thousand funny capers and grimaces, that the Animals were carried entirely off their feet with enthusiasm, and then and there, elected him their king.
title: The Fox and the Monkey
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The Fox did not vote for the Monkey and was much disgusted with the Animals for electing so unworthy a ruler.
title: The Fox and the Monkey
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: One day he found a trap with a bit of meat in it.
title: The Fox and the Monkey
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Hurrying to King Monkey, he told him he had found a rich treasure, which he had not touched because it belonged by right to his majesty the Monkey.
title: The Fox and the Monkey
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The greedy Monkey followed the Fox to the trap.
title: The Fox and the Monkey
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: As soon as he saw the meat he grasped eagerly for it, only to find himself held fast in the trap.
title: The Fox and the Monkey
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The Fox stood off and laughed.
title: The Fox and the Monkey
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "You pretend to be our king," he said, "and cannot even take care of yourself!"
title: The Fox and the Monkey
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Shortly after that, another election among the Animals was held.
title: The Fox and the Monkey
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: There was once a Dog who was so ill-natured and mischievous that his Master had to fasten a heavy wooden clog about his neck to keep him from annoying visitors and neighbors.
title: The Mischievous Dog
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: But the Dog seemed to be very proud of the clog and dragged it about noisily as if he wished to attract everybody's attention.
title: The Mischievous Dog
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: He was not able to impress anyone.
title: The Mischievous Dog
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "You would be wiser," said an old acquaintance, "to keep quietly out of sight with that clog.
title: The Mischievous Dog
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Do you want everybody to know what a disgraceful and ill-natured Dog you are?"
title: The Mischievous Dog
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: An Eagle, swooping down on powerful wings, seized a lamb in her talons and made off with it to her nest.
title: The Eagle and the Jackdaw
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: A Jackdaw saw the deed, and his silly head was filled with the idea that he was big and strong enough to do as the Eagle had done.
title: The Eagle and the Jackdaw
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: So with much rustling of feathers and a fierce air, he came down swiftly on the back of a large Ram.
title: The Eagle and the Jackdaw
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: But when he tried to rise again he found that he could not get away, for his claws were tangled in the wool.
title: The Eagle and the Jackdaw
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: And so far was he from carrying away the Ram, that the Ram hardly noticed he was there.
title: The Eagle and the Jackdaw
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The Shepherd saw the fluttering Jackdaw and at once guessed what had happened.
title: The Eagle and the Jackdaw
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Running up, he caught the bird and clipped its wings.
title: The Eagle and the Jackdaw
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: That evening he gave the Jackdaw to his children.
title: The Eagle and the Jackdaw
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "What a funny bird this is!"
title: The Eagle and the Jackdaw
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: they said laughing, "what do you call it, father?"
title: The Eagle and the Jackdaw
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "That is a Jackdaw, my children.
title: The Eagle and the Jackdaw
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: But if you should ask him, he would say he is an Eagle."
title: The Eagle and the Jackdaw
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Once upon a time a Cat and a Monkey lived as pets in the same house.
title: The Monkey and the Cat
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: They were great friends and were constantly in all sorts of mischief together.
title: The Monkey and the Cat
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: What they seemed to think of more than anything else was to get something to eat, and it did not matter much to them how they got it.
title: The Monkey and the Cat
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: One day they were sitting by the fire, watching some chestnuts roasting on the hearth.
title: The Monkey and the Cat
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: How to get them was the question.
title: The Monkey and the Cat
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "I would gladly get them," said the cunning Monkey, "but you are much more skillful at such things than I am.
title: The Monkey and the Cat
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Pull them out and I'll divide them between us."
title: The Monkey and the Cat
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Pussy stretched out her paw very carefully, pushed aside some of the cinders, and drew back her paw very quickly.
title: The Monkey and the Cat
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Then she tried it again, this time pulling a chestnut half out of the fire.
title: The Monkey and the Cat
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: A third time and she drew out the chestnut.
title: The Monkey and the Cat
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: This performance she went through several times, each time singeing her paw severely.
title: The Monkey and the Cat
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: As fast as she pulled the chestnuts out of the fire, the Monkey ate them up.
title: The Monkey and the Cat
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Now the master came in, and away scampered the rascals, Mistress Cat with a burnt paw and no chestnuts.
title: The Monkey and the Cat
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: From that time on, they say, she contented herself with mice and rats and had little to do with Sir Monkey.
title: The Monkey and the Cat
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: A certain Father had a family of Sons, who were forever quarreling among themselves.
title: The Bundle of Sticks
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: No words he could say did the least good, so he cast about in his mind for some very striking example that should make them see that discord would lead them to misfortune.
title: The Bundle of Sticks
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: One day when the quarreling had been much more violent than usual and each of the Sons was moping in a surly manner, he asked one of them to bring him a bundle of sticks.
title: The Bundle of Sticks
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Then handing the bundle to each of his Sons in turn he told them to try to break it.
title: The Bundle of Sticks
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: But although each one tried his best, none was able to do so.
title: The Bundle of Sticks
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The Father then untied the bundle and gave the sticks to his Sons to break one by one.
title: The Bundle of Sticks
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: This they did very easily.
title: The Bundle of Sticks
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "My Sons," said the Father, "do you not see how certain it is that if you agree with each other and help each other, it will be impossible for your enemies to injure you?
title: The Bundle of Sticks
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: But if you are divided among yourselves, you will be no stronger than a single stick in that bundle."
title: The Bundle of Sticks
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: A Wild Boar was sharpening his tusks busily against the stump of a tree, when a Fox happened by.
title: The Wild Boar and the Fox
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Now the Fox was always looking for a chance to make fun of his neighbors.
title: The Wild Boar and the Fox
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: So he made a great show of looking anxiously about, as if in fear of some hidden enemy.
title: The Wild Boar and the Fox
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: But the Boar kept right on with his work.
title: The Wild Boar and the Fox
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "Why are you doing that?"
title: The Wild Boar and the Fox
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: asked the Fox at last with a grin.
title: The Wild Boar and the Fox
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "There isn't any danger that I can see."
title: The Wild Boar and the Fox
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "True enough," replied the Boar, "but when danger does come there will not be time for such work as this.
title: The Wild Boar and the Fox
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: My weapons will have to be ready for use then, or I shall suffer for it."
title: The Wild Boar and the Fox
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: A frisky young Kid had been left by the herdsman on the thatched roof of a sheep shelter to keep him out of harm's way.
title: The Kid and the Wolf
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The Kid was browsing near the edge of the roof, when he spied a Wolf and began to jeer at him, making faces and abusing him to his heart's content.
title: The Kid and the Wolf
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "I hear you," said the Wolf, "and I haven't the least grudge against you for what you say or do.
title: The Kid and the Wolf
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: When you are up there it is the roof that's talking, not you."
title: The Kid and the Wolf
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: A pack of Wolves lurked near the Sheep pasture.
title: The Wolves and the Sheep
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: But the Dogs kept them all at a respectful distance, and the Sheep grazed in perfect safety.
title: The Wolves and the Sheep
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: But now the Wolves thought of a plan to trick the Sheep.
title: The Wolves and the Sheep
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "Why is there always this hostility between us?"
title: The Wolves and the Sheep
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: they said.
title: The Wolves and the Sheep
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "If it were not for those Dogs who are always stirring up trouble, I am sure we should get along beautifully.
title: The Wolves and the Sheep
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Send them away and you will see what good friends we shall become."
title: The Wolves and the Sheep
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The Sheep were easily fooled.
title: The Wolves and the Sheep
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: They persuaded the Dogs to go away, and that very evening the Wolves had the grandest feast of their lives.
title: The Wolves and the Sheep
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: A Rat was traveling along the King's highway.
title: The Rat and the Elephant
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: He was a very proud Rat, considering his small size and the bad reputation all Rats have.
title: The Rat and the Elephant
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: As Mr. Rat walked along—he kept mostly to the ditch—he noticed a great commotion up the road, and soon a grand procession came in view.
title: The Rat and the Elephant
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: It was the King and his retinue.
title: The Rat and the Elephant
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The King rode on a huge Elephant adorned with the most gorgeous trappings.
title: The Rat and the Elephant
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: With the King in his luxurious howdah were the royal Dog and Cat.
title: The Rat and the Elephant
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: A great crowd of people followed the procession.
title: The Rat and the Elephant
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: They were so taken up with admiration of the Elephant, that the Rat was not noticed.
title: The Rat and the Elephant
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: His pride was hurt.
title: The Rat and the Elephant
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "What fools!"
title: The Rat and the Elephant
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: he cried.
title: The Rat and the Elephant
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "Look at me, and you will soon forget that clumsy Elephant!
title: The Rat and the Elephant
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Is it his great size that makes your eyes pop out?
title: The Rat and the Elephant
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Or is it his wrinkled hide?
title: The Rat and the Elephant
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Why, I have eyes and ears and as many legs as he!
title: The Rat and the Elephant
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: I am of just as much importance, and"—
title: The Rat and the Elephant
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: But just then the royal Cat spied him, and the next instant, the Rat knew he was not quite so important as an Elephant.
title: The Rat and the Elephant
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Once upon a time a severe plague raged among the animals.
title: The Animals and the Plague
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Many died, and those who lived were so ill, that they cared for neither food nor drink, and dragged themselves about listlessly.
title: The Animals and the Plague
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: No longer could a fat young hen tempt Master Fox to dinner, nor a tender lamb rouse greedy Sir Wolf's appetite.
title: The Animals and the Plague
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: At last the Lion decided to call a council.
title: The Animals and the Plague
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: When all the animals were gathered together he arose and said:
title: The Animals and the Plague
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "Dear friends, I believe the gods have sent this plague upon us as a punishment for our sins.
title: The Animals and the Plague
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Therefore, the most guilty one of us must be offered in sacrifice.
title: The Animals and the Plague
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Perhaps we may thus obtain forgiveness and cure for all.
title: The Animals and the Plague
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "I will confess all my sins first.
title: The Animals and the Plague
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: I admit that I have been very greedy and have devoured many sheep.
title: The Animals and the Plague
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: They had done me no harm.
title: The Animals and the Plague
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: I have eaten goats and bulls and stags.
title: The Animals and the Plague
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: To tell the truth, I even ate up a shepherd now and then.
title: The Animals and the Plague
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "Now, if I am the most guilty, I am ready to be sacrificed.
title: The Animals and the Plague
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: But I think it best that each one confess his sins as I have done.
title: The Animals and the Plague
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Then we can decide in all justice who is the most guilty."
title: The Animals and the Plague
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "Your majesty," said the Fox, "you are too good.
title: The Animals and the Plague
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Can it be a crime to eat sheep, such stupid mutton heads?
title: The Animals and the Plague
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: No, no, your majesty.
title: The Animals and the Plague
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: You have done them great honor by eating them up.
title: The Animals and the Plague
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "And so far as shepherds are concerned, we all know they belong to that puny race that pretends to be our masters."
title: The Animals and the Plague
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: All the animals applauded the Fox loudly.
title: The Animals and the Plague
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Then, though the Tiger, the Bear, the Wolf, and all the savage beasts recited the most wicked deeds, all were excused and made to appear very saint-like and innocent.
title: The Animals and the Plague
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: It was now the Ass's turn to confess.
title: The Animals and the Plague
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "I remember," he said guiltily, "that one day as I was passing a field belonging to some priests, I was so tempted by the tender grass and my hunger, that I could not resist nibbling a bit of it.
title: The Animals and the Plague
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: I had no right to do it, I admit—"
title: The Animals and the Plague
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: A great uproar among the beasts interrupted him.
title: The Animals and the Plague
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Here was the culprit who had brought misfortune on all of them!
title: The Animals and the Plague
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: What a horrible crime it was to eat grass that belonged to someone else!
title: The Animals and the Plague
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: It was enough to hang anyone for, much more an Ass.
title: The Animals and the Plague
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Immediately they all fell upon him, the Wolf in the lead, and soon had made an end to him, sacrificing him to the gods then and there, and without the formality of an altar.
title: The Animals and the Plague
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: There was once an Ass whose Master also owned a Lap Dog.
title: The Ass and the Lap Dog
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: This Dog was a favorite and received many a pat and kind word from his Master, as well as choice bits from his plate.
title: The Ass and the Lap Dog
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Every day the Dog would run to meet the Master, frisking playfully about and leaping up to lick his hands and face.
title: The Ass and the Lap Dog
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: All this the Ass saw with much discontent.
title: The Ass and the Lap Dog
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Though he was well fed, he had much work to do; besides, the Master hardly ever took any notice of him.
title: The Ass and the Lap Dog
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Now the jealous Ass got it into his silly head that all he had to do to win his Master's favor was to act like the Dog.
title: The Ass and the Lap Dog
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: So one day he left his stable and clattered eagerly into the house.
title: The Ass and the Lap Dog
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Finding his Master seated at the dinner table, he kicked up his heels and, with a loud bray, pranced giddily around the table, upsetting it as he did so.
title: The Ass and the Lap Dog
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Then he planted his forefeet on his Master's knees and rolled out his tongue to lick the Master's face, as he had seen the Dog do.
title: The Ass and the Lap Dog
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: But his weight upset the chair, and Ass and man rolled over together in the pile of broken dishes from the table.
title: The Ass and the Lap Dog
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The Master was much alarmed at the strange behavior of the Ass, and calling for help, soon attracted the attention of the servants.
title: The Ass and the Lap Dog
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: When they saw the danger the Master was in from the clumsy beast, they set upon the Ass and drove him with kicks and blows back to the stable.
title: The Ass and the Lap Dog
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: There they left him to mourn the foolishness that had brought him nothing but a sound beating.
title: The Ass and the Lap Dog
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Two Goats, frisking gayly on the rocky steeps of a mountain valley, chanced to meet, one on each side of a deep chasm through which poured a mighty mountain torrent.
title: The Two Goats
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The trunk of a fallen tree formed the only means of crossing the chasm, and on this not even two squirrels could have passed each other in safety.
title: The Two Goats
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The narrow path would have made the bravest tremble.
title: The Two Goats
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Not so our Goats.
title: The Two Goats
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Their pride would not permit either to stand aside for the other.
title: The Two Goats
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: One set her foot on the log.
title: The Two Goats
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The other did likewise.
title: The Two Goats
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: In the middle they met horn to horn.
title: The Two Goats
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Neither would give way, and so they both fell, to be swept away by the roaring torrent below.
title: The Two Goats
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: There was once a Cat who was so watchful, that a Mouse hardly dared show the tip of his whiskers for fear of being eaten alive.
title: The Cat and the Old Rat
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: That Cat seemed to be everywhere at once with his claws all ready for a pounce.
title: The Cat and the Old Rat
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: At last the Mice kept so closely to their dens, that the Cat saw he would have to use his wits well to catch one.
title: The Cat and the Old Rat
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: So one day he climbed up on a shelf and hung from it, head downward, as if he were dead, holding himself up by clinging to some ropes with one paw.
title: The Cat and the Old Rat
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: When the Mice peeped out and saw him in that position, they thought he had been hung up there in punishment for some misdeed.
title: The Cat and the Old Rat
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Very timidly at first they stuck out their heads and sniffed about carefully.
title: The Cat and the Old Rat
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: But as nothing stirred, all trooped joyfully out to celebrate the death of the Cat.
title: The Cat and the Old Rat
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Just then the Cat let go his hold, and before the Mice recovered from their surprise, he had made an end of three or four.
title: The Cat and the Old Rat
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Now the Mice kept more strictly at home than ever.
title: The Cat and the Old Rat
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: But the Cat, who was still hungry for Mice, knew more tricks than one.
title: The Cat and the Old Rat
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Rolling himself in flour until he was covered completely, he lay down in the flour bin, with one eye open for the Mice.
title: The Cat and the Old Rat
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Sure enough, the Mice soon began to come out.
title: The Cat and the Old Rat
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: To the Cat it was almost as if he already had a plump young Mouse under his claws, when an old Rat, who had had much experience with Cats and traps, and had even lost a part of his tail to pay for it, sat up at a safe distance from a hole in the wall where he lived.
title: The Cat and the Old Rat
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "Take care!"
title: The Cat and the Old Rat
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: he cried.
title: The Cat and the Old Rat
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "That may be a heap of meal, but it looks to me very much like the Cat.
title: The Cat and the Old Rat
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Whatever it is, it is wisest to keep at a safe distance."
title: The Cat and the Old Rat
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: A very young Fox, who had never before seen a Lion, happened to meet one in the forest.
title: The Fox and the Lion
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: A single look was enough to send the Fox off at top speed for the nearest hiding place.
title: The Fox and the Lion
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The second time the Fox saw the Lion he stopped behind a tree to look at him a moment before slinking away.
title: The Fox and the Lion
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: But the third time, the Fox went boldly up to the Lion and, without turning a hair, said, "Hello, there, old top."

source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: It happened once upon a time that a certain Greek ship bound for Athens was wrecked off the coast close to Piraeus, the port of Athens.
title: The Monkey and the Dolphin
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Had it not been for the Dolphins, who at that time were very friendly toward mankind and especially toward Athenians, all would have perished.
title: The Monkey and the Dolphin
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: But the Dolphins took the shipwrecked people on their backs and swam with them to shore.
title: The Monkey and the Dolphin
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Now it was the custom among the Greeks to take their pet monkeys and dogs with them whenever they went on a voyage.
title: The Monkey and the Dolphin
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: So when one of the Dolphins saw a Monkey struggling in the water, he thought it was a man, and made the Monkey climb up on his back.
title: The Monkey and the Dolphin
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Then off he swam with him toward the shore.
title: The Monkey and the Dolphin
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The Monkey sat up, grave and dignified, on the Dolphin's back.
title: The Monkey and the Dolphin
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "You are a citizen of illustrious Athens, are you not?"
title: The Monkey and the Dolphin
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: asked the Dolphin politely.
title: The Monkey and the Dolphin
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "Yes," answered the Monkey, proudly.
title: The Monkey and the Dolphin
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "My family is one of the noblest in the city."
title: The Monkey and the Dolphin
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "Indeed," said the Dolphin.
title: The Monkey and the Dolphin
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "Then of course you often visit Piraeus."
title: The Monkey and the Dolphin
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "Yes, yes," replied the Monkey.
title: The Monkey and the Dolphin
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "Indeed, I do.
title: The Monkey and the Dolphin
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: I am with him constantly.
title: The Monkey and the Dolphin
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Piraeus is my very best friend."
title: The Monkey and the Dolphin
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: This answer took the Dolphin by surprise, and, turning his head, he now saw what it was he was carrying.
title: The Monkey and the Dolphin
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Without more ado, he dived and left the foolish Monkey to take care of himself, while he swam off in search of some human being to save.
title: The Monkey and the Dolphin
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: A Boy, stung by a Nettle, ran home crying, to get his mother to blow on the hurt and kiss it.
title: The Boy and the Nettle
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "Son," said the Boy's mother, when she had comforted him, "the next time you come near a Nettle, grasp it firmly, and it will be as soft as silk."
title: The Boy and the Nettle
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The Lion had been badly hurt by the horns of a Goat, which he was eating.
title: The Hare and His Ears
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: He was very angry to think that any animal that he chose for a meal, should be so brazen as to wear such dangerous things as horns to scratch him while he ate.
title: The Hare and His Ears
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: So he commanded that all animals with horns should leave his domains within twenty-four hours.
title: The Hare and His Ears
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The command struck terror among the beasts.
title: The Hare and His Ears
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: All those who were so unfortunate as to have horns, began to pack up and move out.
title: The Hare and His Ears
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Even the Hare, who, as you know, has no horns and so had nothing to fear, passed a very restless night, dreaming awful dreams about the fearful Lion.
title: The Hare and His Ears
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: And when he came out of the warren in the early morning sunshine, and there saw the shadow cast by his long and pointed ears, a terrible fright seized him.
title: The Hare and His Ears
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "Goodby, neighbor Cricket," he called.
title: The Hare and His Ears
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "I'm off.
title: The Hare and His Ears
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: He will certainly make out that my ears are horns, no matter what I say."
title: The Hare and His Ears
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: A young fellow, who was very popular among his boon companions as a good spender, quickly wasted his fortune trying to live up to his reputation.
title: The Spendthrift and the Swallow
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Then one fine day in early spring he found himself with not a penny left, and no property save the clothes he wore.
title: The Spendthrift and the Swallow
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: He was to meet some jolly young men that morning, and he was at his wits' end how to get enough money to keep up appearances.
title: The Spendthrift and the Swallow
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Just then a Swallow flew by, twittering merrily, and the young man, thinking summer had come, hastened off to a clothes dealer, to whom he sold all the clothes he wore down to his very tunic.
title: The Spendthrift and the Swallow
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: A few days later a change in weather brought a severe frost; and the poor swallow and that foolish young man in his light tunic, and with his arms and knees bare, could scarcely keep life in their shivering bodies.
title: The Spendthrift and the Swallow
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: A Town Mouse once visited a relative who lived in the country.
title: The Town Mouse and the Country Mouse
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: For lunch the Country Mouse served wheat stalks, roots, and acorns, with a dash of cold water for drink.
title: The Town Mouse and the Country Mouse
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The Town Mouse ate very sparingly, nibbling a little of this and a little of that, and by her manner making it very plain that she ate the simple food only to be polite.
title: The Town Mouse and the Country Mouse
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: After the meal the friends had a long talk, or rather the Town Mouse talked about her life in the city while the Country Mouse listened.
title: The Town Mouse and the Country Mouse
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: They then went to bed in a cozy nest in the hedgerow and slept in quiet and comfort until morning.
title: The Town Mouse and the Country Mouse
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: In her sleep the Country Mouse dreamed she was a Town Mouse with all the luxuries and delights of city life that her friend had described for her.
title: The Town Mouse and the Country Mouse
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: So the next day when the Town Mouse asked the Country Mouse to go home with her to the city, she gladly said yes.
title: The Town Mouse and the Country Mouse
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: When they reached the mansion in which the Town Mouse lived, they found on the table in the dining room the leavings of a very fine banquet.
title: The Town Mouse and the Country Mouse
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: There were sweetmeats and jellies, pastries, delicious cheeses, indeed, the most tempting foods that a Mouse can imagine.
title: The Town Mouse and the Country Mouse
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: But just as the Country Mouse was about to nibble a dainty bit of pastry, she heard a Cat mew loudly and scratch at the door.
title: The Town Mouse and the Country Mouse
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: In great fear the Mice scurried to a hiding place, where they lay quite still for a long time, hardly daring to breathe.
title: The Town Mouse and the Country Mouse
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: When at last they ventured back to the feast, the door opened suddenly and in came the servants to clear the table, followed by the House Dog.
title: The Town Mouse and the Country Mouse
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The Country Mouse stopped in the Town Mouse's den only long enough to pick up her carpet bag and umbrella.
title: The Town Mouse and the Country Mouse
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "You may have luxuries and dainties that I have not," she said as she hurried away, "but I prefer my plain food and simple life in the country with the peace and security that go with it."
title: The Town Mouse and the Country Mouse
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: A Hare was making fun of the Tortoise one day for being so slow.

source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "Do you ever get anywhere?"

source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: he asked with a mocking laugh.
title: The Hare and the Tortoise
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "Yes," replied the Tortoise, "and I get there sooner than you think.
title: The Hare and the Tortoise
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: I'll run you a race and prove it."
title: The Hare and the Tortoise
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The Hare was much amused at the idea of running a race with the Tortoise, but for the fun of the thing he agreed.
title: The Hare and the Tortoise
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: So the Fox, who had consented to act as judge, marked the distance and started the runners off.
title: The Hare and the Tortoise
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The Hare was soon far out of sight, and to make the Tortoise feel very deeply how ridiculous it was for him to try a race with a Hare, he lay down beside the course to take a nap until the Tortoise should catch up.

source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The Tortoise meanwhile kept going slowly but steadily, and, after a time, passed the place where the Hare was sleeping.
title: The Hare and the Tortoise
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: But the Hare slept on very peacefully; and when at last he did wake up, the Tortoise was near the goal.
title: The Hare and the Tortoise
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The Hare now ran his swiftest, but he could not overtake the Tortoise in time.
title: The Hare and the Tortoise
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: A Shepherd, counting his Sheep one day, discovered that a number of them were missing.

source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: But before starting out he made a vow to Jupiter that if he would help him find the thief he would offer a fat Calf as a sacrifice.

source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The Shepherd searched a long time without finding any Wolves, but just as he was passing near a large cave on the mountain side, a huge Lion stalked out, carrying a Sheep.

source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: In great terror the Shepherd fell on his knees.
title: The Shepherd and the Lion
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "Alas, O Jupiter, man does not know what he asks!
title: The Shepherd and the Lion
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: To find the thief I offered to sacrifice a fat Calf.
title: The Shepherd and the Lion
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Now I promise you a full-grown Bull, if you but make the thief go away!"

source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Two Travelers were walking along the seashore.

source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: That is some fisherman's skiff, with the day's catch of savoury fish."

source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Still nearer came the object.

source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The waves washed it up on shore.

source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "It is a chest of gold lost from some wreck," they cried.

source: The Aesop for Children

source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: One cold stormy day a Goatherd drove his Goats for shelter into a cave, where a number of Wild Goats had also found their way.

sentence: "We know how you would treat us later on, if some strangers should come as we did."

sentence: A poor Woodman was cutting down a tree near the edge of a deep pool in the forest.

source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: It was late in the day and the Woodman was tired.

source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: He had been working since sunrise and his strokes were not so sure as they had been early that morning.

source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Thus it happened that the axe slipped and flew out of his hands into the pool.

source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The Woodman was in despair.

source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The axe was all he possessed with which to make a living, and he had not money enough to buy a new one.
title: Mercury and the Woodman
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: As he stood wringing his hands and weeping, the god Mercury suddenly appeared and asked what the trouble was.

source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The Woodman told what had happened, and straightway the kind Mercury dived into the pool.

source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: When he came up again he held a wonderful golden axe.

source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "Is this your axe?"
title: Mercury and the Woodman
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Mercury asked the Woodman.
title: Mercury and the Woodman
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "No," answered the honest Woodman, "that is not my axe."
title: Mercury and the Woodman
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Mercury laid the golden axe on the bank and sprang back into the pool.
title: Mercury and the Woodman
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: This time he brought up an axe of silver, but the Woodman declared again that his axe was just an ordinary one with a wooden handle.

source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Mercury dived down for the third time, and when he came up again he had the very axe that had been lost.

source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The poor Woodman was very glad that his axe had been found and could not thank the kind god enough.

source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Mercury was greatly pleased with the Woodman's honesty.

source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "I admire your honesty," he said, "and as a reward you may have all three axes, the gold and the silver as well as your own."

source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The happy Woodman returned to his home with his treasures, and soon the story of his good fortune was known to everybody in the village.

source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Now there were several Woodmen in the village who believed that they could easily win the same good fortune.

source: The Aesop for Children

source: The Aesop for Children

source: The Aesop for Children

source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: To each one he showed an axe of gold, and each one eagerly claimed it to be the one he had lost.

source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: But Mercury did not give them the golden axe.

source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Oh no!

source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Instead he gave them each a hard whack over the head with it and sent them home.
title: Mercury and the Woodman
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: And when they returned next day to look for their own axes, they were nowhere to be found.

source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: A Fox was caught in a trap one fine morning, because he had got too near the Farmer's hen house.
title: The Cock and the Fox (2)
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: No doubt he was hungry, but that was not an excuse for stealing.
title: The Cock and the Fox (2)
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: A Cock, rising early, discovered what had happened.

source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: He knew the Fox could not get at him, so he went a little closer to get a good look at his enemy.

source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The Fox saw a slender chance of escape.

source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: But please do not tell anybody about it.

sentence: I dislike causing sorrow to anybody, and I am sure I can soon gnaw this string to pieces."

sentence: But the Cock was not to be so easily fooled.

sentence: The Frogs were tired of governing themselves.
title: The Frogs who Wished for a King
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: They had so much freedom that it had spoiled them, and they did nothing but sit around croaking in a bored manner and wishing for a government that could entertain them with the pomp and display of royalty, and rule them in a way to make them know they were being ruled.
title: The Frogs who Wished for a King
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: No milk and water government for them, they declared.
title: The Frogs who Wished for a King
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: So they sent a petition to Jupiter asking for a king.
title: The Frogs who Wished for a King
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Jupiter saw what simple and foolish creatures they were, but to keep them quiet and make them think they had a king he threw down a huge log, which fell into the water with a great splash.

source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The Frogs hid themselves among the reeds and grasses, thinking the new king to be some fearful giant.
title: The Frogs who Wished for a King
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: But they soon discovered how tame and peaceable King Log was.
title: The Frogs who Wished for a King
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: In a short time the younger Frogs were using him for a diving platform, while the older Frogs made him a meeting place, where they complained loudly to Jupiter about the government.
title: The Frogs who Wished for a King
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: To teach the Frogs a lesson the ruler of the gods now sent a Crane to be king of Frogland.
title: The Frogs who Wished for a King
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The Crane proved to be a very different sort of king from old King Log.
title: The Frogs who Wished for a King
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: He gobbled up the poor Frogs right and left and they soon saw what fools they had been.
title: The Frogs who Wished for a King
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: In mournful croaks they begged Jupiter to take away the cruel tyrant before they should all be destroyed.
title: The Frogs who Wished for a King
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "How now!"
title: The Frogs who Wished for a King
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: cried Jupiter "Are you not yet content?
title: The Frogs who Wished for a King
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: You have what you asked for and so you have only yourselves to blame for your misfortunes."
title: The Frogs who Wished for a King
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The Dog could creep inside and the Cock would fly up on one of the branches.
title: The Dog, the Cock, and the Fox

sentence: So said, so done, and both slept very comfortably.

sentence: He thought he was still in the farmyard where it had been his duty to arouse the household at daybreak.
