sentence: "If you will please go around to the door of my house at the foot of the tree, my porter will let you in."
title: The Dog, the Cock, and the Fox
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The hungry but unsuspecting Fox, went around the tree as he was told, and in a twinkling the Dog had seized him.
title: The Dog, the Cock, and the Fox
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: A Wolf had stolen a Lamb and was carrying it off to his lair to eat it.
title: The Wolf and the Lion
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: But his plans were very much changed when he met a Lion, who, without making any excuses, took the Lamb away from him.
title: The Wolf and the Lion
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The Wolf made off to a safe distance, and then said in a much injured tone:
title: The Wolf and the Lion
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "You have no right to take my property like that!"
title: The Wolf and the Lion
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The Lion looked back, but as the Wolf was too far away to be taught a lesson without too much inconvenience, he said:
title: The Wolf and the Lion
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "Your property?
title: The Wolf and the Lion
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Did you buy it, or did the Shepherd make you a gift of it?
title: The Wolf and the Lion
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Pray tell me, how did you get it?"
title: The Wolf and the Lion
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: A Wolf had been hurt in a fight with a Bear.
title: The Wolf and the Sheep
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: He was unable to move and could not satisfy his hunger and thirst.
title: The Wolf and the Sheep
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: A Sheep passed by near his hiding place, and the Wolf called to him.
title: The Wolf and the Sheep
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "Please fetch me a drink of water," he begged, "that might give me strength enough so I can get me some solid food."
title: The Wolf and the Sheep
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "Solid food!"
title: The Wolf and the Sheep
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: said the Sheep.
title: The Wolf and the Sheep
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "That means me, I suppose.
title: The Wolf and the Sheep
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: If I should bring you a drink, it would only serve to wash me down your throat.
title: The Wolf and the Sheep
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Don't talk to me about a drink!"
title: The Wolf and the Sheep
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: A Cock was busily scratching and scraping about to find something to eat for himself and his family, when he happened to turn up a precious jewel that had been lost by its owner.
title: The Cock and the Jewel
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "Aha!"
title: The Cock and the Jewel
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: said the Cock.
title: The Cock and the Jewel
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "No doubt you are very costly and he who lost you would give a great deal to find you.
title: The Cock and the Jewel
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: But as for me, I would choose a single grain of barleycorn before all the jewels in the world."
title: The Cock and the Jewel
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: An Ox came down to a reedy pool to drink.
title: The Frogs and the Ox
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: As he splashed heavily into the water, he crushed a young Frog into the mud.
title: The Frogs and the Ox
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The old Frog soon missed the little one and asked his brothers and sisters what had become of him.
title: The Frogs and the Ox
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "A great big monster," said one of them, "stepped on little brother with one of his huge feet!"
title: The Frogs and the Ox
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "Big, was he!"
title: The Frogs and the Ox
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: said the old Frog, puffing herself up.
title: The Frogs and the Ox
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "Was he as big as this?"
title: The Frogs and the Ox
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "Oh, much bigger!"
title: The Frogs and the Ox
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: they cried.
title: The Frogs and the Ox
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The Frog puffed up still more.
title: The Frogs and the Ox
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "He could not have been bigger than this," she said.
title: The Frogs and the Ox
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: But the little Frogs all declared that the monster was much, much bigger and the old Frog kept puffing herself out more and more until, all at once, she burst.
title: The Frogs and the Ox
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: A Lion had grown very old.
title: The Old Lion
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: His teeth were worn away.
title: The Old Lion
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: His limbs could no longer bear him, and the King of Beasts was very pitiful indeed as he lay gasping on the ground, about to die.
title: The Old Lion
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Where now his strength and his former graceful beauty?
title: The Old Lion
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Now a Boar spied him, and rushing at him, gored him with his yellow tusk.
title: The Old Lion
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: A Bull trampled him with his heavy hoofs.
title: The Old Lion
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Even a contemptible Ass let fly his heels and brayed his insults in the face of the Lion.
title: The Old Lion
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: A Lion and an Ass agreed to go hunting together.
title: The Lion and the Ass (2)
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: In their search for game the hunters saw a number of Wild Goats run into a cave, and laid plans to catch them.
title: The Lion and the Ass (2)
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The Ass was to go into the cave and drive the Goats out, while the Lion would stand at the entrance to strike them down.
title: The Lion and the Ass (2)
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The plan worked beautifully.
title: The Lion and the Ass (2)
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The Ass made such a frightful din in the cave, kicking and braying with all his might, that the Goats came running out in a panic of fear, only to fall victim to the Lion.
title: The Lion and the Ass (2)
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The Ass came proudly out of the cave.
title: The Lion and the Ass (2)
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "Did you see how I made them run?"
title: The Lion and the Ass (2)
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: he said.
title: The Lion and the Ass (2)
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "Yes, indeed," answered the Lion, "and if I had not known you and your kind I should certainly have run, too."
title: The Lion and the Ass (2)
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: A Jackdaw chanced to fly over the garden of the King's palace.
title: The Vain Jackdaw and his Borrowed Feathers
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: There he saw with much wonder and envy a flock of royal Peacocks in all the glory of their splendid plumage.
title: The Vain Jackdaw and his Borrowed Feathers
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Now the black Jackdaw was not a very handsome bird, nor very refined in manner.
title: The Vain Jackdaw and his Borrowed Feathers
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Yet he imagined that all he needed to make himself fit for the society of the Peacocks was a dress like theirs.
title: The Vain Jackdaw and his Borrowed Feathers
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: So he picked up some castoff feathers of the Peacocks and stuck them among his own black plumes.
title: The Vain Jackdaw and his Borrowed Feathers
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Dressed in his borrowed finery he strutted loftily among the birds of his own kind.
title: The Vain Jackdaw and his Borrowed Feathers
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Then he flew down into the garden among the Peacocks.
title: The Vain Jackdaw and his Borrowed Feathers
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: But they soon saw who he was.
title: The Vain Jackdaw and his Borrowed Feathers
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Angry at the cheat, they flew at him, plucking away the borrowed feathers and also some of his own.
title: The Vain Jackdaw and his Borrowed Feathers
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The poor Jackdaw returned sadly to his former companions.
title: The Vain Jackdaw and his Borrowed Feathers
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: There another unpleasant surprise awaited him.
title: The Vain Jackdaw and his Borrowed Feathers
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: They had not forgotten his superior airs toward them, and, to punish him, they drove him away with a rain of pecks and jeers.
title: The Vain Jackdaw and his Borrowed Feathers
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "Away with you, vile insect!"
title: The Lion and the Gnat
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: said a Lion angrily to a Gnat that was buzzing around his head.
title: The Lion and the Gnat
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: But the Gnat was not in the least disturbed.
title: The Lion and the Gnat
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "Do you think," he said spitefully to the Lion, "that I am afraid of you because they call you king?"
title: The Lion and the Gnat
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The next instant he flew at the Lion and stung him sharply on the nose.
title: The Lion and the Gnat
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Mad with rage, the Lion struck fiercely at the Gnat, but only succeeded in tearing himself with his claws.
title: The Lion and the Gnat
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Again and again the Gnat stung the Lion, who now was roaring terribly.
title: The Lion and the Gnat
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: At last, worn out with rage and covered with wounds that his own teeth and claws had made, the Lion gave up the fight.
title: The Lion and the Gnat
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The Gnat buzzed away to tell the whole world about his victory, but instead he flew straight into a spider's web.
title: The Lion and the Gnat
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: And there, he who had defeated the King of beasts came to a miserable end, the prey of a little spider.
title: The Lion and the Gnat
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: An Ass was being driven along a road leading down the mountain side, when he suddenly took it into his silly head to choose his own path.
title: The Ass and his Driver
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: He could see his stall at the foot of the mountain, and to him the quickest way down seemed to be over the edge of the nearest cliff.
title: The Ass and his Driver
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Just as he was about to leap over, his master caught him by the tail and tried to pull him back, but the stubborn Ass would not yield and pulled with all his might.
title: The Ass and his Driver
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "Very well," said his master, "go your way, you willful beast, and see where it leads you."
title: The Ass and his Driver
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: With that he let go, and the foolish Ass tumbled head over heels down the mountain side.
title: The Ass and his Driver
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: A man who lived a long time ago believed that he could read the future in the stars.
title: The Astrologer
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: He called himself an Astrologer, and spent his time at night gazing at the sky.
title: The Astrologer
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: One evening he was walking along the open road outside the village.
title: The Astrologer
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: His eyes were fixed on the stars.
title: The Astrologer
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: He thought he saw there that the end of the world was at hand, when all at once, down he went into a hole full of mud and water.
title: The Astrologer
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: There he stood up to his ears, in the muddy water, and madly clawing at the slippery sides of the hole in his effort to climb out.
title: The Astrologer
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: His cries for help soon brought the villagers running.
title: The Astrologer
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: As they pulled him out of the mud, one of them said:
title: The Astrologer
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "You pretend to read the future in the stars, and yet you fail to see what is at your feet!
title: The Astrologer
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: This may teach you to pay more attention to what is right in front of you, and let the future take care of itself."
title: The Astrologer
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "What use is it," said another, "to read the stars, when you can't see what's right here on the earth?"
title: The Astrologer
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: A Fox one day spied a beautiful bunch of ripe grapes hanging from a vine trained along the branches of a tree.
title: The Fox and the Grapes
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The grapes seemed ready to burst with juice, and the Fox's mouth watered as he gazed longingly at them.
title: The Fox and the Grapes
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The bunch hung from a high branch, and the Fox had to jump for it.
title: The Fox and the Grapes
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The first time he jumped he missed it by a long way.
title: The Fox and the Grapes
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: So he walked off a short distance and took a running leap at it, only to fall short once more.
title: The Fox and the Grapes
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Again and again he tried, but in vain.
title: The Fox and the Grapes
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Now he sat down and looked at the grapes in disgust.
title: The Fox and the Grapes
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "What a fool I am," he said.
title: The Fox and the Grapes
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "Here I am wearing myself out to get a bunch of sour grapes that are not worth gaping for."
title: The Fox and the Grapes
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: And off he walked very, very scornfully.
title: The Fox and the Grapes
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: A Milkmaid had been out to milk the cows and was returning from the field with the shining milk pail balanced nicely on her head.
title: The Milkmaid and Her Pail
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: As she walked along, her pretty head was busy with plans for the days to come.
title: The Milkmaid and Her Pail
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "This good, rich milk," she mused, "will give me plenty of cream to churn.
title: The Milkmaid and Her Pail
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The butter I make I will take to market, and with the money I get for it I will buy a lot of eggs for hatching.
title: The Milkmaid and Her Pail
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: How nice it will be when they are all hatched and the yard is full of fine young chicks.
title: The Milkmaid and Her Pail
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Then when May day comes I will sell them, and with the money I'll buy a lovely new dress to wear to the fair.
title: The Milkmaid and Her Pail
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: All the young men will look at me.
title: The Milkmaid and Her Pail
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: They will come and try to make love to me,—but I shall very quickly send them about their business!"
title: The Milkmaid and Her Pail
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: As she thought of how she would settle that matter, she tossed her head scornfully, and down fell the pail of milk to the ground.
title: The Milkmaid and Her Pail
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: And all the milk flowed out, and with it vanished butter and eggs and chicks and new dress and all the milkmaid's pride.
title: The Milkmaid and Her Pail
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: A Fox and a Leopard, resting lazily after a generous dinner, amused themselves by disputing about their good looks.
title: The Fox and the Leopard
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The Leopard was very proud of his glossy, spotted coat and made disdainful remarks about the Fox, whose appearance he declared was quite ordinary.
title: The Fox and the Leopard
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The Fox prided himself on his fine bushy tail with its tip of white, but he was wise enough to see that he could not rival the Leopard in looks.
title: The Fox and the Leopard
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Still he kept up a flow of sarcastic talk, just to exercise his wits and to have the fun of disputing.
title: The Fox and the Leopard
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The Leopard was about to lose his temper when the Fox got up, yawning lazily.
title: The Fox and the Leopard
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "You may have a very smart coat," he said, "but you would be a great deal better off if you had a little more smartness inside your head and less on your ribs, the way I am.
title: The Fox and the Leopard
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: That's what I call real beauty."
title: The Fox and the Leopard
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: A Farmer walked through his field one cold winter morning.
title: The Farmer and the Snake
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: On the ground lay a Snake, stiff and frozen with the cold.
title: The Farmer and the Snake
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The Farmer knew how deadly the Snake could be, and yet he picked it up and put it in his bosom to warm it back to life.
title: The Farmer and the Snake
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The Snake soon revived, and when it had enough strength, bit the man who had been so kind to it.
title: The Farmer and the Snake
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The bite was deadly and the Farmer felt that he must die.
title: The Farmer and the Snake
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: As he drew his last breath, he said to those standing around: Learn from my fate not to take pity on a scoundrel.
title: The Farmer and the Snake
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: A Cat was growing very thin.
title: The Cat and the Birds
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: As you have guessed, he did not get enough to eat.
title: The Cat and the Birds
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: One day he heard that some Birds in the neighborhood were ailing and needed a doctor.
title: The Cat and the Birds
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: So he put on a pair of spectacles, and with a leather box in his hand, knocked at the door of the Bird's home.
title: The Cat and the Birds
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The Birds peeped out, and Dr. Cat, with much solicitude, asked how they were.
title: The Cat and the Birds
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: He would be very happy to give them some medicine.
title: The Cat and the Birds
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "Tweet, tweet," laughed the Birds.
title: The Cat and the Birds
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "Very smart, aren't you?
title: The Cat and the Birds
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: We are very well, thank you, and more so, if you only keep away from here."
title: The Cat and the Birds
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: A Merchant, driving his Ass homeward from the seashore with a heavy load of salt, came to a river crossed by a shallow ford.
title: The Ass and the Load of Salt
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: They had crossed this river many times before without accident, but this time the Ass slipped and fell when halfway over.
title: The Ass and the Load of Salt
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: And when the Merchant at last got him to his feet, much of the salt had melted away.
title: The Ass and the Load of Salt
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Delighted to find how much lighter his burden had become, the Ass finished the journey very gayly.
title: The Ass and the Load of Salt
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Next day the Merchant went for another load of salt.
title: The Ass and the Load of Salt
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: On the way home the Ass, remembering what had happened at the ford, purposely let himself fall into the water, and again got rid of most of his burden.
title: The Ass and the Load of Salt
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The angry Merchant immediately turned about and drove the Ass back to the seashore, where he loaded him with two great baskets of sponges.
title: The Ass and the Load of Salt
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: At the ford the Ass again tumbled over; but when he had scrambled to his feet, it was a very disconsolate Ass that dragged himself homeward under a load ten times heavier than before.
title: The Ass and the Load of Salt
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The Swallow and the Crow had an argument one day about their plumage.
title: The Swallow and the Crow
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Said the Swallow: "Just look at my bright and downy feathers.
title: The Swallow and the Crow
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Your black stiff quills are not worth having.
title: The Swallow and the Crow
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Why don't you dress better?
title: The Swallow and the Crow
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Show a little pride!"
title: The Swallow and the Crow
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "Your feathers may do very well in spring," replied the Crow, "but—I don't remember ever having seen you around in winter, and that's when I enjoy myself most."
title: The Swallow and the Crow
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: A Serpent had succeeded in surprising an Eagle and had wrapped himself around the Eagle's neck.
title: The Serpent and the Eagle
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The Eagle could not reach the Serpent, neither with beak nor claws.
title: The Serpent and the Eagle
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Far into the sky he soared trying to shake off his enemy.
title: The Serpent and the Eagle
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: But the Serpent's hold only tightened, and slowly the Eagle sank back to earth, gasping for breath.
title: The Serpent and the Eagle
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: A Countryman chanced to see the unequal combat.
title: The Serpent and the Eagle
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: In pity for the noble Eagle he rushed up and soon had loosened the coiling Serpent and freed the Eagle.
title: The Serpent and the Eagle
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The Serpent was furious.
title: The Serpent and the Eagle
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: He had no chance to bite the watchful Countryman.
title: The Serpent and the Eagle
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Instead he struck at the drinking horn, hanging at the Countryman's belt, and into it let fly the poison of his fangs.
title: The Serpent and the Eagle
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The Countryman now went on toward home.
title: The Serpent and the Eagle
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Becoming thirsty on the way, he filled his horn at a spring, and was about to drink.
title: The Serpent and the Eagle
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: There was a sudden rush of great wings.
title: The Serpent and the Eagle
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Sweeping down, the Eagle seized the poisoned horn from out his savior's hands, and flew away with it to hide it where it could never be found.
title: The Serpent and the Eagle
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: An old Lion, whose teeth and claws were so worn that it was not so easy for him to get food as in his younger days, pretended that he was sick.
title: The Old Lion and the Fox
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: He took care to let all his neighbors know about it, and then lay down in his cave to wait for visitors.
title: The Old Lion and the Fox
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: And when they came to offer him their sympathy, he ate them up one by one.
title: The Old Lion and the Fox
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The Fox came too, but he was very cautious about it.
title: The Old Lion and the Fox
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Standing at a safe distance from the cave, he inquired politely after the Lion's health.
title: The Old Lion and the Fox
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The Lion replied that he was very ill indeed, and asked the Fox to step in for a moment.
title: The Old Lion and the Fox
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: But Master Fox very wisely stayed outside, thanking the Lion very kindly for the invitation.
title: The Old Lion and the Fox
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "I should be glad to do as you ask," he added, "but I have noticed that there are many footprints leading into your cave and none coming out.
title: The Old Lion and the Fox
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Pray tell me, how do your visitors find their way out again?"
title: The Old Lion and the Fox
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Some hungry Dogs saw a number of hides at the bottom of a stream where the Tanner had put them to soak.
title: The Dogs and the Hides
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: A fine hide makes an excellent meal for a hungry Dog, but the water was deep and the Dogs could not reach the hides from the bank.
title: The Dogs and the Hides
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: So they held a council and decided that the very best thing to do was to drink up the river.
title: The Dogs and the Hides
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: All fell to lapping up the water as fast as they could.
title: The Dogs and the Hides
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: But though they drank and drank until, one after another, all of them had burst with drinking, still, for all their effort, the water in the river remained as high as ever.
title: The Dogs and the Hides
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: One moonlight evening as Master Fox was taking his usual stroll in the woods, he saw a number of Pheasants perched quite out of his reach on a limb of a tall old tree.
title: The Fox and the Pheasants
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The sly Fox soon found a bright patch of moonlight, where the Pheasants could see him clearly; there he raised himself up on his hind legs, and began a wild dance.
title: The Fox and the Pheasants
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: First he whirled 'round and 'round like a top, then he hopped up and down, cutting all sorts of strange capers.
title: The Fox and the Pheasants
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: The Pheasants stared giddily.
title: The Fox and the Pheasants
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: They hardly dared blink for fear of losing him out of their sight a single instant.
title: The Fox and the Pheasants
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Now the Fox made as if to climb a tree, now he fell over and lay still, playing dead, and the next instant he was hopping on all fours, his back in the air, and his bushy tail shaking so that it seemed to throw out silver sparks in the moonlight.
title: The Fox and the Pheasants
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: By this time the poor birds' heads were in a whirl.
title: The Fox and the Pheasants
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: And when the Fox began his performance all over again, so dazed did they become, that they lost their hold on the limb, and fell down one by one to the Fox.
title: The Fox and the Pheasants
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: A Lark made her nest in a field of young wheat.
title: The Lark and Her Young Ones
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: As the days passed, the wheat stalks grew tall and the young birds, too, grew in strength.
title: The Lark and Her Young Ones
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: Then one day, when the ripe golden grain waved in the breeze, the Farmer and his son came into the field.
title: The Lark and Her Young Ones
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "This wheat is now ready for reaping," said the Farmer.
title: The Lark and Her Young Ones
source: The Aesop for Children

sentence: "We must call in our neighbors and friends to help us harvest it."
title: The Lark and Her Young Ones

sentence: V. There is no immateriality—it is a mere word.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: That which is not matter, is not at all—unless qualities are things.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: P. Is God, then, material?
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: V. No.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: [This reply startled me very much.]
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: P. What, then, is he?
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: V. [After a long pause, and mutteringly.]
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: I see—but it is a thing difficult to tell.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: [Another long pause.]
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: He is not spirit, for he exists.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: Nor is he matter, as you understand it.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: But there are gradations of matter of which man knows nothing; the grosser impelling the finer, the finer pervading the grosser.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: The atmosphere, for example, impels the electric principle, while the electric principle permeates the atmosphere.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: These gradations of matter increase in rarity or fineness, until we arrive at a matter unparticled—without particles—indivisible—one; and here the law of impulsion and permeation is modified.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: The ultimate, or unparticled matter, not only permeates all things but impels all things; and thus is all things within itself.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: This matter is God.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: What men attempt to embody in the word “thought,” is this matter in motion.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: P. The metaphysicians maintain that all action is reducible to motion and thinking, and that the latter is the origin of the former.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: V. Yes; and I now see the confusion of idea.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: Motion is the action of mind, not of thinking.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: The unparticled matter, or God, in quiescence, is (as nearly as we can conceive it) what men call mind.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: And the power of self-movement (equivalent in effect to human volition) is, in the unparticled matter, the result of its unity and omniprevalence; how I know not, and now clearly see that I shall never know.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: But the unparticled matter, set in motion by a law, or quality, existing within itself, is thinking.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: P. Can you give me no more precise idea of what you term the unparticled matter?
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: V. The matters of which man is cognizant escape the senses in gradation.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: We have, for example, a metal, a piece of wood, a drop of water, the atmosphere, a gas, caloric, electricity, the luminiferous ether.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: Now we call all these things matter, and embrace all matter in one general definition; but in spite of this, there can be no two ideas more essentially distinct than that which we attach to a metal, and that which we attach to the luminiferous ether.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: When we reach the latter, we feel an almost irresistible inclination to class it with spirit, or with nihility.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: The only consideration which restrains us is our conception of its atomic constitution; and here, even, we have to seek aid from our notion of an atom, as something possessing in infinite minuteness, solidity, palpability, weight.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: Destroy the idea of the atomic constitution and we should no longer be able to regard the ether as an entity, or at least as matter.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: For want of a better word we might term it spirit.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: Take, now, a step beyond the luminiferous ether—conceive a matter as much more rare than the ether, as this ether is more rare than the metal, and we arrive at once (in spite of all the school dogmas) at a unique mass—an unparticled matter.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: For although we may admit infinite littleness in the atoms themselves, the infinitude of littleness in the spaces between them is an absurdity.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: There will be a point—there will be a degree of rarity, at which, if the atoms are sufficiently numerous, the interspaces must vanish, and the mass absolutely coalesce.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: But the consideration of the atomic constitution being now taken away, the nature of the mass inevitably glides into what we conceive of spirit.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: It is clear, however, that it is as fully matter as before.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: The truth is, it is impossible to conceive spirit, since it is impossible to imagine what is not.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: When we flatter ourselves that we have formed its conception, we have merely deceived our understanding by the consideration of infinitely rarified matter.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: P. There seems to me an insurmountable objection to the idea of absolute coalescence;—and that is the very slight resistance experienced by the heavenly bodies in their revolutions through space—a resistance now ascertained, it is true, to exist in some degree, but which is, nevertheless, so slight as to have been quite overlooked by the sagacity even of Newton.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: We know that the resistance of bodies is, chiefly, in proportion to their density.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: Absolute coalescence is absolute density.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: Where there are no interspaces, there can be no yielding.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: An ether, absolutely dense, would put an infinitely more effectual stop to the progress of a star than would an ether of adamant or of iron.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: V. Your objection is answered with an ease which is nearly in the ratio of its apparent unanswerability.—As regards the progress of the star, it can make no difference whether the star passes through the ether or the ether through it.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: There is no astronomical error more unaccountable than that which reconciles the known retardation of the comets with the idea of their passage through an ether: for, however rare this ether be supposed, it would put a stop to all sidereal revolution in a very far briefer period than has been admitted by those astronomers who have endeavored to slur over a point which they found it impossible to comprehend.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: The retardation actually experienced is, on the other hand, about that which might be expected from the friction of the ether in the instantaneous passage through the orb.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: In the one case, the retarding force is momentary and complete within itself—in the other it is endlessly accumulative.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: P. But in all this—in this identification of mere matter with God—is there nothing of irreverence?
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: [I was forced to repeat this question before the sleep-waker fully comprehended my meaning.]
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: V. Can you say why matter should be less reverenced than mind?
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: But you forget that the matter of which I speak is, in all respects, the very “mind” or “spirit” of the schools, so far as regards its high capacities, and is, moreover, the “matter” of these schools at the same time.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: God, with all the powers attributed to spirit, is but the perfection of matter.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: P. You assert, then, that the unparticled matter, in motion, is thought?
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: V. In general, this motion is the universal thought of the universal mind.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: This thought creates.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: All created things are but the thoughts of God.

source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: P. You say, “in general.”
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: V. Yes.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: The universal mind is God.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: For new individualities, matter is necessary.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: P. But you now speak of “mind” and “matter” as do the metaphysicians.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: V. Yes—to avoid confusion.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: When I say “mind,” I mean the unparticled or ultimate matter; by “matter,” I intend all else.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: P. You were saying that “for new individualities matter is necessary.”
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: V. Yes; for mind, existing unincorporate, is merely God.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: To create individual, thinking beings, it was necessary to incarnate portions of the divine mind.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: Thus man is individualized.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: Divested of corporate investiture, he were God.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: Now, the particular motion of the incarnated portions of the unparticled matter is the thought of man; as the motion of the whole is that of God.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: P. You say that divested of the body man will be God?
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: V. [After much hesitation.]
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: I could not have said this; it is an absurdity.
title: Mesmeric Revelation

sentence: P. [Referring to my notes.]
title: Mesmeric Revelation

sentence: You did say that “divested of corporate investiture man were God.”
title: Mesmeric Revelation

sentence: V. And this is true.

sentence: Man thus divested would be God—would be unindividualized.

sentence: Man is a creature.

sentence: What we call “death,” is but the painful metamorphosis.

sentence: Our future is perfected, ultimate, immortal.

sentence: The ultimate life is the full design.

sentence: V. We, certainly—but not the worm.

sentence: The matter of which our rudimental body is composed, is within the ken of the organs of that body; or, more distinctly, our rudimental organs are adapted to the matter of which is formed the rudimental body; but not to that of which the ultimate is composed.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: The ultimate body thus escapes our rudimental senses, and we perceive only the shell which falls, in decaying, from the inner form; not that inner form itself; but this inner form, as well as the shell, is appreciable by those who have already acquired the ultimate life.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: P. You have often said that the mesmeric state very nearly resembles death.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: How is this?
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: V. When I say that it resembles death, I mean that it resembles the ultimate life; for when I am entranced the senses of my rudimental life are in abeyance, and I perceive external things directly, without organs, through a medium which I shall employ in the ultimate, unorganized life.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: P. Unorganized?
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: V. Yes; organs are contrivances by which the individual is brought into sensible relation with particular classes and forms of matter, to the exclusion of other classes and forms.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: The organs of man are adapted to his rudimental condition, and to that only; his ultimate condition, being unorganized, is of unlimited comprehension in all points but one—the nature of the volition of God—that is to say, the motion of the unparticled matter.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: You will have a distinct idea of the ultimate body by conceiving it to be entire brain.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: This it is not; but a conception of this nature will bring you near a comprehension of what it is.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: A luminous body imparts vibration to the luminiferous ether.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: The vibrations generate similar ones within the retina; these again communicate similar ones to the optic nerve.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: The nerve conveys similar ones to the brain; the brain, also, similar ones to the unparticled matter which permeates it.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: The motion of this latter is thought, of which perception is the first undulation.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: This is the mode by which the mind of the rudimental life communicates with the external world; and this external world is, to the rudimental life, limited, through the idiosyncrasy of its organs.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: But in the ultimate, unorganized life, the external world reaches the whole body, (which is of a substance having affinity to brain, as I have said,) with no other intervention than that of an infinitely rarer ether than even the luminiferous; and to this ether—in unison with it—the whole body vibrates, setting in motion the unparticled matter which permeates it.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: It is to the absence of idiosyncratic organs, therefore, that we must attribute the nearly unlimited perception of the ultimate life.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: To rudimental beings, organs are the cages necessary to confine them until fledged.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: P. You speak of rudimental “beings.” Are there other rudimental thinking beings than man?
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: V. The multitudinous conglomeration of rare matter into nebulæ, planets, suns, and other bodies which are neither nebulæ, suns, nor planets, is for the sole purpose of supplying pabulum for the idiosyncrasy of the organs of an infinity of rudimental beings.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: But for the necessity of the rudimental, prior to the ultimate life, there would have been no bodies such as these.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: Each of these is tenanted by a distinct variety of organic, rudimental, thinking creatures.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: In all, the organs vary with the features of the place tenanted.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: At death, or metamorphosis, these creatures, enjoying the ultimate life—immortality—and cognizant of all secrets but the one, act all things and pass everywhere by mere volition:—indwelling, not the stars, which to us seem the sole palpabilities, and for the accommodation of which we blindly deem space created—but that SPACE itself—that infinity of which the truly substantive vastness swallows up the star-shadows—blotting them out as non-entities from the perception of the angels.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: P. You say that “but for the necessity of the rudimental life” there would have been no stars.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: But why this necessity?
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: V. In the inorganic life, as well as in the inorganic matter generally, there is nothing to impede the action of one simple unique law—the Divine Volition.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: With the view of producing impediment, the organic life and matter, (complex, substantial, and law-encumbered,) were contrived.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: P. But again—why need this impediment have been produced?
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: V. The result of law inviolate is perfection—right—negative happiness.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: The result of law violate is imperfection, wrong, positive pain.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: Through the impediments afforded by the number, complexity, and substantiality of the laws of organic life and matter, the violation of law is rendered, to a certain extent, practicable.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: Thus pain, which in the inorganic life is impossible, is possible in the organic.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: P. But to what good end is pain thus rendered possible?
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: V. All things are either good or bad by comparison.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: A sufficient analysis will show that pleasure, in all cases, is but the contrast of pain.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: Positive pleasure is a mere idea.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: To be happy at any one point we must have suffered at the same.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: Never to suffer would have been never to have been blessed.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: But it has been shown that, in the inorganic life, pain cannot be thus the necessity for the organic.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: The pain of the primitive life of Earth, is the sole basis of the bliss of the ultimate life in Heaven.
title: Mesmeric Revelation
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: P. Still, there is one of your expressions which I find it impossible to comprehend—“the truly substantive vastness of infinity.”
title: Mesmeric Revelation

sentence: V. This, probably, is because you have no sufficiently generic conception of the term “substance” itself.

sentence: We must not regard it as a quality, but as a sentiment:—it is the perception, in thinking beings, of the adaptation of matter to their organization.

sentence: There are many things on the Earth, which would be nihility to the inhabitants of Venus—many things visible and tangible in Venus, which we could not be brought to appreciate as existing at all.

sentence: But to the inorganic beings—to the angels—the whole of the unparticled matter is substance—that is to say, the whole of what we term “space” is to them the truest substantiality;—the stars, meantime, through what we consider their materiality, escaping the angelic sense, just in proportion as the unparticled matter, through what we consider its immateriality, eludes the organic.
title: Mesmeric Revelation

sentence: No sooner had I done this, than, with a bright smile irradiating all his features, he fell back upon his pillow and expired.

sentence: From his cradle to his grave a gale of prosperity bore my friend Ellison along.

sentence: I mean it as synonymous with happiness.

sentence: The person of whom I speak seemed born for the purpose of foreshadowing the doctrines of Turgot, Price, Priestley, and Condorcet—of exemplifying by individual instance what has been deemed the chimera of the perfectionists.
title: The Domain of Arnheim
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: In the brief existence of Ellison I fancy that I have seen refuted the dogma, that in man’s very nature lies some hidden principle, the antagonist of bliss.
title: The Domain of Arnheim
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: An anxious examination of his career has given me to understand that in general, from the violation of a few simple laws of humanity arises the wretchedness of mankind—that as a species we have in our possession the as yet unwrought elements of content—and that, even now, in the present darkness and madness of all thought on the great question of the social condition, it is not impossible that man, the individual, under certain unusual and highly fortuitous conditions, may be happy.
title: The Domain of Arnheim
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: With opinions such as these my young friend, too, was fully imbued, and thus it is worthy of observation that the uninterrupted enjoyment which distinguished his life was, in great measure, the result of preconcert.
title: The Domain of Arnheim
source: The Works of Edgar Allen Poe Vol. 2

sentence: It is indeed evident that with less of the instinctive philosophy which, now and then, stands so well in the stead of experience, Mr. Ellison would have found himself precipitated, by the very extraordinary success of his life, into the common vortex of unhappiness which yawns for those of pre-eminent endowments.
title: The Domain of Arnheim

sentence: But it is by no means my object to pen an essay on happiness.

sentence: That which he considered chief was (strange to say!)

sentence: “The health,” he said, “attainable by other means is scarcely worth the name.” He instanced the ecstasies of the fox-hunter, and pointed to the tillers of the earth, the only people who, as a class, can be fairly considered happier than others.

sentence: His third, and most difficult of realization, was the contempt of ambition.

sentence: His fourth was an object of unceasing pursuit; and he held that, other things being equal, the extent of attainable happiness was in proportion to the spirituality of this object.

sentence: Ellison was remarkable in the continuous profusion of good gifts lavished upon him by fortune.
